content: My PR #24127 is not on the review queue but it says it is on the page "Why is my PR not on the queue?". Is it possible it has something to do with the fact that I added the awaiting author label back after realizing I made a minor mistake and then removed it myself?
This topic was moved here from #PR reviews > #24127 PR not on the review queue. by David Ledvinka.

Also the "Why is my PR not on the queue?" page says my new PR #24241 is coming from a fork, even though from my perspective I used exactly the same process to start this as my previous PRs. I am worried I did something weird that is messing them both up?
This second issue seems to have fixed itself (with #24241) but not #24127
I see both PRs as shown in the queue now.
(I can look into the "why" of previous states later, possibly tomorrow.)

I just found a moment to investigate:

  • the #24241 incident was because the queueboard did not have correct data for that PR - which fixed itself over time. (Unfortunately, "ensure all data is always up to date" is harder than I'd like - otherwise, I'd have fully fixed this long ago.)

• when you posted your comment, #24127 was still marked awaiting-author --- which means it's not on the review queue. If you address a reviewer's comments, you must also remove the awaiting-author label, otherwise the computers don't know you addressed all of them.

(In general, that webpage takes about 15 minutes to update after a change is made. Johan Commelin and I are investigating making this faster, but some technical details are... harder. That doesn't seem pertinent here, though.)

Thanks! For #24127, of course this happened quite a while ago so I may have misremembered but am pretty confident that I both removed the awaiting-author tag (that I had added myself) as well as on the "Why is my PR not on the queue page?" all columns were checked and the final column said "awaiting review". I think it was about 12 hours between removing the tag and posting my comment but perhaps it just took an unusually long time to update.

Ah, I didn't realise the relevant label change was a bit earlier. I dug a bit deeper - indeed, this was an instance of the metadata taking unusually long to update. (There was a hiccup in data downloading, whose fix took some time to fully work.) Thanks for reporting this, though!
